results.title: My grandmother
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Elizabeth Leek
results.brief_description: Elizabeth lived with her grandmother in a little village in Sudan. This story is a dedication to her grandmother, a woman who taught her many things.

results.title: Dancing again
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Hannan Kuea
results.brief_description: Hannan Kuea reminisces about her childhood and life in Sudan and especially her wedding day - this very special day to be the last of the families getting together in Sudan before the married couple move on to Kenya and finally to Australia. On this wedding day the families (one side from North Sudan, the other from South Sudan) danced their traditional tribal dances in celebration. It would be many years later before the families reunite to dance once again in their new land on the other side of the world.

results.title: The Cows of Sudan
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Mary Hoth
results.brief_description: Nayaluak Beche recounts her farming life in Sudan where the women milk the cows and the men farm the land. She describes the cultures and traditions of women growing up in Sudan, her marriage and subsequent children and grandchildren and her decision to finally leave her homeland to join her daughter in Australia.
results.description: Nayaluak Beche recounts her farming life in Sudan where the women milk the cows and the men farm the land. results.title: The Blue Nile
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Kathrine Deng
results.brief_description: Through civil war Kathrine’s family are forced to change their lives, language and religion and eventually their country. Kathrine and her family are now living in Australia and they feel safe and have a chance to realise their dreams. Kathrine wants to make sure her children understand their cultural heritage and hopes that one day she can show them the Blue Nile.

results.title: Dust (On Wheels )
results.brief_description:
Two groups of teenagers - a white brother and sister, and two Aboriginal mates - come together to find work on a dusty cotton field in the outback. What they discover hidden in the ground, is history itself. Switching effortlessly from the naturalism of the relationships between the youth to the grandeur of the mythic power and terror of the resolution, this short film is an exemplary example of contemporary Australian cinema.
Mick is young, white and angry at the world. His sister Amy is trying to keep it all together, not an easy task when Mick seems determined to screw things up. Leroy is afraid his future holds nothing beyond this life in the mirage of a dusty field. His best mate Vance works alongside him, more interested in Amy than chipping weeds. Ruby, Leroy’s mother is the only one who notices when the uneasy sky forces the elements to merge. As a violent dust storm awakes, racial differences must be put aside as the five shelter in Leroy’s car. Australia’s history, black and white, is revealed as the storm unearths the secrets that lie beneath the surface of the land.

results.title: Public hangings
results.brief_description: Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for and broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The programs style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 2. Ep. 01
results.brief_description:
Episode number 14 of Series “Public hangings”.
Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program (now in its second series) produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Andrew MacKenzie introduces a packed program. Tim Danko curates at Westspace “Paper Skin - Constructed Guts” an exhibition of the work of thirty contemporary local and overseas comic book producers/artists. Brendan Tolley, Kirrily Schell and Cassandra Tytler are a few of the artists. Nat & Ali provide more comic relief with their lived-in performance on opening night. At Linden St Kilda Contemporary Arts is ‘High Tide’, a photographic exhibition by contemporary indigenous artists looking at the landscape. Curated by Christian Thompson the artists include; Destiny Deacon, Brenda Croft, Michael Riley, Jenny Fraser, Jason Hampton and Dianne Jones. An excerpt of Michael Riley’s film ‘Empire’ is included with music by Anthony Parthos performed by the Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra (first screened on ABC 2000). At Ian Potter Museum of Art ‘It’s a Beautiful Day’ opens. An exhibition exploring the gamut of contemporary painting that includes the work of Peter Booth, Brent Harris, Vivien Shark le Wit, Anne Wallace and David Jolly to name a few. Curated by Bala Starr.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 1. Ep. 13
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Public hangings”.
Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode, Andrew MacKenzie presents a show of his favourite bits from the first series. This includes: The opening of the Helen Lempriere National Sculpture Prize, ‘Neo Noir’ at Gertrude Contemporary Art Spaces, ‘Art Bites’ community project in Parkdale, ‘Comic Book Lifestyle’ Linden St Kilda Centre for Contemporary Arts, Sticky - the comic book shop and James Meldrum at Mira Gallery.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 1. Ep. 12
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Public hangings”.
Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Lena Corner interviews Luke Sinclair and Anya Latham about their evolving autobiographical (and collaborative) set of installations at Platform. Melbourne City Councils ‘Laneways Project’ is launched with the work of David Williams and Carol Porter whose collaborative public work looks at the Chinese role in the Melbourne community by exploring the history of the Chen family, early Melbourne settlers. Andrew Stevens talks about his not-for-profit art space in Footscray, ‘Shopfront’. John-Paul Hussey performs his critically reviewed autobiographical one-man show ‘The Chocolate Monkey’ at Gammaspace. Screen Talk this week looks at the video work of Starlie Gieki whose work centres around themes of victimhood and the image of women.
